bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Jessie Daniel Ames, May 16, 1956

div1.p: Hench informs Ames that he is trying to get her husband recognition for his medical care of the yellow fever volunteers.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Jessie Daniel Ames, May 16, 1956
div1.opener:
May 16, 1956
Mrs. Jessie Daniel Ames
Wrens Nest
Tryon, North Carolina
My dear Mrs. Ames:
div1.p:
We have not corresponded since our pleasant meeting in Cuba at the time of the dedica-
tion of Camp Lazear, when you received the Cuban decoration. I was very happy about
that affair.

I must not raise false hopes, but the incredible just might happen. I have known, of
course, that Lambert has for years been appealing to Congress in behalf of a bill to
honor Doctor Ames but of course Lambert would himself be included. I know that
friends of yours in earlier years tried to do the same for Doctor Ames. Yet all of
these efforts were in vain. I myself decided that they were without success because
Lambert was trying to change the categories created in 1929 and was trying to erase
an important distinction. Although Lambert very rightly claims to have exposed him-
self to yellow fever in almost every possible way while he nursed the yellow fever
victims, nevertheless he did not actually have injected into his body, by mosquito or
needle, the live yellow fever virus and that is an important distinction. Through
the years, I have made various inquiries through Generals Kean, Truby and Ireland,
and also through the various Surgeons General, as to the possibility of honoring
Doctor Ames and Mr. Lambert because I do think that both of them served in a real
sense beyond the call of duty. I was always discouraged and again the reason was
the very real distinction mentioned above.

Recently Lambert made another try through his Illinois Congressman and, presumably, he
was again attempting to have the bill passed in favor of Doctor Ames. But by Congres-
sional manipulation of some sort (I don't quite understand it), it turned out to be a
bill to add Lambert's name to the Roll of Honor without mentioning Doctor Ames. The
excuses given were that (1) an Illinois Congressman could not introduce a bill to
honor a former citizen from another state; now the Congressmen from the respective
states have the responsibility and privilege of initiating honors in favor of living
or deceased citizens of their states and (2) after all, Lambert is living, is crippled,
old and almost blind. He is the one that needs help; the pension is the important
thing. An honor for someone no longer here is of less practical consequence.

After a bill in favor of Lambert had been worded and already passed by the appropriate
committee of the House of Representatives, I was asked to support it. I wrestled
with my conscience for two weeks. The question was whether, if this bill did not
pass, Lambert might die before receiving an honor and should I therefore approve this
bill and help it to be passed or should my very real objections to the exclusion of
Doctor Ames make me object to the bill as now stated. Although I am most sympathetic
to Lambert (and have been trying to honor him and Doctor Ames in my own ways for
several years, via the memorialization and dedication of Camp Lazear, the bronze
Mrs. Ames - 2 - May 16, 1956
plaque and the encouragement of the Cuban Government to honor Doctor Ames and
Mr. Lambert and the others), I just could not accept the exclusion of Doctor Ames,
which has been done apparently on the grounds of political expediency. Therefore
I visited the Surgeon General's Office about two or three months ago and discussed
matters with those concerned. They seemed to agree that Doctor Ames should be in-
cluded. I was surprised, therefore, to find shortly thereafter that the so-called
Lambert Bill (H.R. 5590) had been passed by the House and was now in the hands of
the Senate Committee on Armed Services, Senator Richard B. Russell, Chairman.

I wrote to him and sent copies of my letters to the President of the Walter Reed
Memorial Association - General Love, living in Washington, and to the Surgeon General's
Office and asked to be allowed to make a counter proposal and, if possible, testify
at any hearing they might have before this bill would be passed by the Committee on
Armed Services. Their replies were encouraging. General Love and Colonel Siler got
in touch with Senator Russell's office and with the Surgeon General's Office and
found them sympathetic to my proposition.

Last week, therefore, in Washington I visited Senator Russell's Executive Assistant
and discussed matters with Major MacKenzie of the Surgeon General's Office, and
with Colonel Siler and General Love of the Walter Reed Memorial Association. I
also found them ostensibly quite sympathetic to my proposition. I returned home
last night and have been advised to divide my proposition into various parts and to
send it at once to the above mentioned parties. Senator Russell's assistant told me
he thought he understood matters so well now that it would not be necessary for me
to add much documentation to my proposition, that is documentation regarding the
services of Doctor Ames and nurse Lambert. He said that there would probably be no
public hearings or hearings of any sort but that the bill might be taken up quickly
toward the end of the session and passed quickly. He thought there was considerable
sentiment in favor of the bill as now constituted (the Lambert bill) and thought
that we could simply use the same number on the bill and amend it by more or less
changing the entire wording. He did warn me that the bill might not be taken up at
all this year; on the other hand, he thought himself that it would be and that it
had a good chance of passage. Major MacKenzie from the Surgeon General's Office
seemed to think so also.

I asked Senator Russell's assistant as to whether the new bill (or the old bill re-
worded) would have to have the support of Louisiana Congressmen and Senators to have
Doctor Ames name included. He thought not but because of what I was told (mentioned
above) I asked him if it wouldn't be much better if we could enlist the support of
Louisiana Congressmen and Senators and he agreed that their support might be quite
helpful. I am therefore asking you to get in touch at once with your Congressmen
and your Senators to have them give whatever support to the new bill they can. How
the Senate Committee will word the new bill, I haven't the faintest idea but they
advised me to state my propositions (and divide the possibilities) as I have given
them in the Addendum. Mr. William H. Darden, Senator Russell's Executive Assistant,
told me that if the Committee found much sentiment, they might pass the whole
Proposition No. 1. If they were less enthusiastic, they might pass Propositions 2 or
3. If they were inclined to be in a hurry and act differently than they always have
in the past, they might even act on Proposition No. 4, but I am not myself urging
Proposition No. 4 because it is the very one that has been defeated so many times
before and I personally feel there is more chance of passing one of the other three
propositions than No. 4. I hope you agree with me. For your convenience, I enclose
three copies of the addendum - my propositions, and one carbon of this letter.

In summary, the bill as it now stands, already passed by the House and under
favorable consideration by the Senate Committee on Armed Services, is simply to
add the name of Lambert (not that of Doctor Ames) to the 1929 Bill. But because
both houses have on every previous occasion objected to adding any names to the
1929 Bill, some of us believe that a rewording - to include Doctor Ames and to do
what the Surgeon General's Office and Congress has always wanted to do before,
that is maintain the distinction mentioned above - might have much more chance
of passage and would probably satisfy all concerned.
div1.closer:
Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M.D. PSH:alc
P.S.: I understand that Lambert, although pleased of course that an honor may
come to him, is very distressed at the exclusion of Doctor Ames and I think he is
quite sincere in this. I am writing in the hope that he will approve the new sug-
gestions.
P.P.S.: I shall at once look up the World Almanac to find the names of the Louisiana
Congressmen that should be contacted and I too will write them. I am going on the
assumption, of course, that Doctor Ames was a Louisiana citizen, a voter in that
state, etc. Did he die there? At your very earliest convenience, could you get to
me (possibly by next Monday) a paragraph telling me what Doctor Ames did after
the yellow fever business, where and when he died, also the names of your Congress-
man and Senator, to confirm my own opinion.
